headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: 17 Hostages Freed On Day Three Of Truce; Israel's War Cabinet Mulling Over Extension Of Gaza Truce; Aid Worker Tells About Life Inside Gaza; Egypt Says 120 Aid Trucks Enter Gaza Through Rafah Border; 3 Palestinian College Students Shot In Vermont. Aired 6-7p ET

utterances.speaker: ALEX MARQUARDT, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: You are live in the NEWSROOM. I'm Alex Marquardt in Washington alongside my colleague Kaitlan Collins who is in Tel Aviv. Jim Acosta is off tonight. Thank you very much for being with us.We are continuing with our breaking news coverage of the war between Israel and Hamas. A nightmare that began seven weeks ago has finally ended for several Israeli families. Today a third group of hostages was finally released from the Gaza Strip. In just the past few hours, we've watched as they arrived at hospitals in Israel to be reunited finally with their loved ones. And for the first time tonight, we are also seeing some of those emotional moments. Families inside hospitals finally embracing after weeks of heartbreak and uncertainty. These are 13 of the 14 Israeli hostages released today, women and children. 13 of them ranging in age from 4 to 84 years old. There was a 14th Israeli who was also a Russian national, and then three more foreign nationals also freed today, bringing the total to 17. Today we saw the first successful release of a young American hostage. This was 4-year-old Abigail Edan. She turned 4 while in captivity just a few days ago. Her parents were killed by Hamas on October 7th. President Joe Biden has spoken with her family tonight. He says he's hopeful that the four-day truce can be extended to allow more hostages to be released. Kaitlan, I can't help but think that as we see these reunions, these joyful moments between parents reuniting with their children, specifically the one between Tom and Emily Hand yesterday, that Abigail is not going to have that. She's coming out, and she has to learn that both of her parents were killed and go on with her life. And of course there is a family that is so ready to welcome her back.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. She's survived by her two siblings who were able to escape on that day. They actually thought that their younger sister had been killed because she was in her father's arms when he was killed. They went and hid in their home. She ran covered in her father's blood to a neighbor's home. And then they were kidnapped into Gaza.And it just -- it speaks to, you know, the word bittersweet doesn't really do it justice, but that is what this moment is for so many of these hostages who are returning home, who are going to hospitals and undergoing these medical evaluations. A lot of them are learning for the first time the full scope of what happened today, whether their loved ones were killed or if they knew that they had been killed because they were killed in front of them, as was the case for Adina Moshe, one of the hostages, that I spoke to her family in recent days. Her husband was buried while she was being held captive. She did not get to go to his funeral. And so you just see moments like that, and it just speaks to the bittersweet nature of all of this. And the question is whether or not there are going to be more hostages brought home after this four-day truce is over, if it's extended. We are now hearing from Hamas for the first time saying they do want to extend that deal. That is not something we had heard from the group so far. But tonight a source does tell me that Israel's War Cabinet here in Tel Aviv has been discussing that possibility. It's not clear where it will end up yet. But as part of this four-day pause that is taking place right now, the one that is under way, an additional 39 Palestinian prisoners and detainees, they were released from Israeli jails today. You saw this moment in the West Bank as they are being welcomed back by their families. Also part of this pause, more than 100 trucks carrying desperately needed aid like food and baby formula arrived in Gaza, in north Gaza, today. I want to bring in CNN's chief global affairs correspondent Matthew Chance. Matthew, you were outside the hospital earlier. Can you just kind of set the scene of what you saw as we've kind of watched this process take place now three times?

utterances.speaker: CHANCE
utterances.sentences: That's right. And, you know, they're a significant proportion of the number of people who are still being held hostage inside Gaza. And what Israel says is that it's going to give people like Jimmy and people like the other -- the Thais as well that have come out, another three came out today, as much care as they can in hospitals inside Israel to make sure they're recovered medically and psychologically as much as possible.It's also interesting, I mean, I spoke to a Foreign Ministry official at one of the hospitals the other day, and he was telling me that each of these people, whether they're Israeli or foreigners, they get a monthly stipend as well of a couple of thousand dollars. And they get that for the rest of their lives. Now it's not much in Israel to live on, but, you know, for people from Thailand, people from the Philippines that do often near kind of agricultural laboring jobs in this country, I mean, that will make a significant difference. And so, you know, this is something. It's a way for Israel to try and sort of, in part, compensate for what they've been through here.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Just in a monetary sense and obviously the care for life that they're going to need for this.Matthew Chance, we'll continue to check in with you as we learn more about the hostages who had been released. For more on what is happening, though, as we are now entering what is going to be the final stage of what has been agreed to so far, this temporary truce is the spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces, Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus. Lieutenant Colonel, it's good to have you on the program again. I just want to first ask you about this request that we are now seeing Hamas weigh in, I guess I should say, on this idea of extending the truce beyond four days when it's set to expire tomorrow. Does that seem like that's likely now that Hamas is saying it also is on board with extending it? LT. COL. JONATHAN CONRICUS, ISRAEL DEFENSE FORCES INTERNATIONAL SPOKESPERSON: Hi, Kaitlan. Thank you for having me again. It's part of the agreement. It's part of the terms that there is this option to extend the pause in return for 10 live -- at least 10 live Israelis per day, and there is room for that in the agreement then that may happen. I have read the reports and I've heard the statements made by the prime minister's office. And of course the IDF will be ready to facilitate that. And as we maintain our readiness to continue operations all over Gaza, we, of course, wait for orders from the Israeli cabinet and having another day of no hostilities in return for 10 Israeli live hostages is, of course, a good deal.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And if that extension does not happen, is your understanding that Tuesday morning at 7

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: How many women and children do you believe, based on what Israel knows so far, are still being held in Gaza tonight?

utterances.speaker: CONRICUS
utterances.sentences: Many, many women. I mean, we're talking about the total number of under 19 was 40 before the first Israeli hostages were released. We've heard some information from Hamas that they allegedly don't know where they are and that they need more time. This sounds like more Hamas lies and manipulations. By the way, they lied about the fact, you know, they've violated the terms of the agreement.They were supposed to not split families, but they released a young Israeli girl, a teenage girl, and they kept her mother Raaya in their captivity. And when we asked about it, they said, well, no, we don't know where she is, only that the daughter tells that they were together up until two days before the release, and they were together the entire time. So we know that Hamas lies. We know that they will try to manipulate and create a difficult situation here. And we're ready to continue fighting. In terms of the other women here, you know, there's female soldiers, and there's women civilians -- COLLINS: Can I ask you -- Lieutenant Colonel, can I ask you? I do want to follow up on that, though, because you're talking about Hila Rotem, and she was separated from her mom. She was the first hostage we've seen who we knew was being held with her mother that wasn't released with her mother. What's your suspicion of why Hamas did not release her mom?

utterances.speaker: CONRICUS
utterances.sentences: They're preying on the feelings of Israelis, as simple as that. They want to manipulate. They want to create more suffering. They want to leverage each and every Israeli in their captivity for political pressure. They think that they can buy their way out of this situation that they have forced upon us, this war, and that they want to use the civilian hostages in order to try to survive and see yet another day. This will fail. By whatever means necessary, Israel will finish the business with Hamas, and at the end of this war, the hostages will be home. That is our commitment. And Hamas will be dismantled.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Does Israel have evidence that Hamas has been moving any of the hostages in this period of the pause in fighting?

utterances.speaker: CONRICUS
utterances.sentences: We have indications of it, yes, that they've been moved around, splitted and then regrouped. As we're speaking, of course, our security agencies are debriefing and asking questions and trying to learn as much as possible from these women and children that have been held for 49 or 51 days. And there's, of course, a lot to learn about the conditions, about where they were held, and any indications that could be substantial for the future.And yes, the working assumption is and the understanding is that they were not static. They were moved around in order to protect them from us, in order to prevent us from getting there and to make it more difficult. Some were a bit more static, but all of these details are now being looked into and assessed as we speak, and they will, I'm sure, be very positive and important for the future.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK. So you have seen that Hamas is moving around the hostages that it does still have in its captivity. I also want to ask you, the Ministry of Health in Gaza is saying that eight Palestinians were killed by Israeli fire in the West Bank in just the last weekend. Can you explain what happened there?

utterances.speaker: CONRICUS
utterances.sentences: So five of them were militants, I suppose. I mean, I cannot, you know, take the Palestinian Health Ministry reports, not in Gaza, not in Judea and Samaria. I have no -- I know of clashes, I know of fighting in Jenin and other locations, some men that took arms against Israeli security personnel and tried to attack civilians. So you'll have to be a little bit more specific when it comes to Palestinian reports for me to be able to respond to it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, I understand that and your skepticism, but what does the IDF say about this? And you say five were militants. We're told that eight of them were killed. What about the other three, sir?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, we needed to ask because we had seen these allegations. We had not seen a comment from the IDF yet. So I wanted to make sure to get you on the record on that, to provide the IDF's explanation.Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Conricus, as always, thank you for your time tonight.

utterances.speaker: CONRICUS
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: We are learning more about life inside Gaza during this war between Israel and Hamas, and during the current truce. Earlier today I spoke with an aid worker named Yousef Hammash. He works for the Norwegian Refugee Council. He lives in Gaza with his family and he told me that people there are hoping that the current truce may lead to a permanent cease-fire but many fear it's only a matter of time before the fighting starts again.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) YOUSEF HAMMASH, NORWEGIAN REFUGEE COUNCIL: People are really hoping and looking for an extending for this truce or this humanitarian pause and looking Gazan authority to reach a permanent cease-fire. But if you look to the people reaction for that, they are feeling lost, and all Gazans are hoping to get any sort of news to extend another few days of humanitarian pause, or it might lead for a cease-fire. We lived these three days, and tomorrow we're going to live the fourth day. But we're preparing ourselves that we might die in the fifth day. That's the situation in Gaza. This is for the first time since seven weeks we were able to walk safely in the streets, sleep safely, be in the streets without having that feeling that you might get bombed at any second. And that's what's going to make it really hard for people to go back into this cycle of violence because even for three days now, people have tasted the sense of safety. A lot of people were using this opportunity to reach for other people who are in the north or Gaza city to check if their house is still there or have been destroyed. And also a lot of people use it as a chance to feel sad and sorrow for their loved ones, who lost them. We didn't have even time to feel sad for our beloved ones that we lose during this seven weeks of madness.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: What have you done during these three days? What have they meant for you?

utterances.speaker: HAMMASH
utterances.sentences: So for three days at least, I managed to reach out for my relatives. Some of them were injured during the bombardment. Now we are going to the winter, and the winter have arrived, and people are not prepared because I'm from the northern part of Gaza. I've lived through (INAUDIBLE) without anything. So I use it also as an opportunity to go and at least find fabric clothes for my children because the weather is going to be hellish, and we have nothing.I have the roof to cover my head, but lots of people, Gazan people doesn't have that option. People are -- we've never seen homeless people in Gaza in our lives. Now it's really common to see people sleeping in the streets and people just looking for any place and consider it as a shelter without any means of protection. And with this weather, it's going to be really, really hard on them to cope with it. I work for a humanitarian organization, and if you combine us all as a humanitarian organization, international organization, U.N. agencies and international organizations, we cannot cover the need for the people in the south. And these four days are not enough, and it's an impossible mission that we can cover the need. All the aid that get in, it did do something, but in terms, comparing to the need unfortunately it's not covering the scale of need that we have. The aid is changing something, but you cannot -- it's not tangible. You cannot feel it because the amount of need is massive.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: And so it sounds like everyone is just hoping that these exchanges just continue so you can drag out this moment of quiet as long as possible. [18But at the same time, there's a recognition that at some point, the violence will start again.

utterances.speaker: HAMMASH
utterances.sentences: People are really hoping that this will get longer and longer. So with every day they extend it, and this humanitarian pause people can breathe more. But also we know that it will be limited if they didn't reach a permanent cease-fire and reach an agreement somehow between all the parties. And that's the responsibility for the international community and world leaders to maintain a solution for the scale of suffering in Gaza. And people are -- all what the people can is hope. Just all what they can do is keep hoping.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: How is your family doing?

utterances.speaker: HAMMASH
utterances.sentences: We are in a survival mood. We all what we have to look for is to survive. I hope I can provide everything for my children and my family, but unfortunately even if you have the financial capacity and have money to afford buying things, you cannot find it. I have two children. Ida (PH) is 5-year-old and Ahmed (PH) 2 1/2. And they witnessed several wars, and my daughter can understand the difference between a missile and tank shell while she's 5 years old.We became experts. Our children became experts in wars. Everyone is responsible for that. The international community and world leaders should do a real action to intervene, to stop this madness that it's affecting more than two million people in this narrow piece of land. We didn't see all of what we see in the news and this propaganda is not enough. We need a real action from people who have the influence and have the ability to stop this madness. It's their responsibility, and I'm really hoping that they stand ahead their responsibilities. It's completely madness, the amount of bombardment, the amount of explosives that have been thrown into Gaza is unimaginable. We were having like an earthquake continue for seven weeks. We were living in earthquake. Our houses were shaking for seven weeks. We were completely disconnected during the bombardment and during this seven weeks, we have been disconnected a few times. We were even disconnected from each other. You don't know what happened the next street because there's no radio, no communication, no internet. We were completely in a blackout, and that was horrific. That experience was really horrific. Especially in this, you know, we are in the telecommunication age and we went through the Stone Ages, totally, in a few seconds, we found ourselves in the Stone Ages. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: The fragile four-day pause in the fighting between Israel and Hamas is set to expire early Tuesday morning local time in Israel and Gaza. But tonight there are talks about extending it. An Israeli source telling CNN that Israel's War Cabinet has met to discuss that possibility of extending the temporary truce in Gaza. This comes after Hamas released a statement saying similar, that it supported the idea.Joining us now to discuss this and more are CNN military analyst and former NATO Supreme Allied commander General Wesley Clark and former State Department Middle East negotiator Aaron David Miller. Thank you both for joining me this evening. General Clark, I want to start with you. Even if this pause is extended, and we're starting to hear positive noises really from all parties, we do expect Israel to start its military operations again. Do you think that the United States is increasing its pressure on how Israel's military should conduct its activities going forward given this extraordinary level of death and destruction that we've seen? GEN. WESLEY CLARK (RET.), CNN MILITARY ANALYST: Well, I think there's a lot of pressure on Israel not only from the United States but from others to somehow contain the level of destruction. Go after Hamas. Do it in some other way. Somehow get rid of the problem, but don't kill so many. Don't damage, don't destroy Gaza the way you've destroyed it. That pressure is real. It's on Israel, and the Israeli military is well aware of it and trying to implement it. But that's a very tall order. It's very difficult to go after Hamas, hiding in civilian buildings behind hostages and other things, and not use kinetic means.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: Aaron, we have seen and heard clear discomfort from within the Biden administration about how Israel is prosecuting this war, certainly when it comes to civilian infrastructure and civilian deaths. Do you have a sense of where the White House is hoping this is going to go in the coming weeks?

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: Yes. Those negotiations for Gilad Shalit, one soldier, lasted years, and now we may have dozens or even scores.General Clark, when it comes to the possibility of a wider war and the fears around that, we have Hezbollah, the militant group to the north in Lebanon, abiding by this pause even though they aren't a party to this deal. We have seen dozens, more than 70 now of smaller attacks on U.S. forces in Iraq and Syria. But if all of these groups haven't really tried in earnest to open another front, do you think that that fear is now over?

utterances.speaker: CLARK
utterances.sentences: I don't think it's over. I think the Israeli military leadership understands full well that what Hamas did, Hezbollah could do, and it could be much more damaging if done by Hezbollah. And they realize they've got to deal not only with the Hamas issue, but they've got to face up to the fact that Hezbollah could do the same thing. Now it depends on how this is resolved obviously.If it's resolved and Hamas is the big loser, then Hezbollah may be deterred. If Hamas comes out of this as a hero for having blunted the Israelis, survived, released Palestinians, and raises its prestige all over the Palestinian cause, well, that incentivizes Hezbollah to follow suit, and the Israelis are going to be watching this very closely. They do not want to do anything that incentivizes Hezbollah to try to imitate Hamas in this. So this fear is not over. What this pause indicates, Alex, is that these groups all communicate. They understand pain. It's a system. It's a way of putting maximum pressure on Israel. Take the hostages, prove your power, and show through global pressure that Israel cannot effectively respond. That's the game. Israel knows it, and Israel is wrestling with it because they want their people back. They want their security.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: Aaron, we only have a couple of moments left. But where do you think the conversation stands about the governance of Gaza and the Palestinian people after this conflict because there has been some daylight between the U.S. and Israel on that? MILLER(INAUDIBLE) reading the best of Golden Trail, she could not tell you. The idea of the Arab states and a security force patrolling the streets of Gaza, quashing Hamas insurgency, not going to work. The Palestinian Authority revitalized maybe, but for the foreseeable future, no way. And they'll demand some sort of Hamas sanction even if the PA is ready to return. So the only thing that I know for certain is that the Israelis are likely, regardless of how this military campaign ends, they're going to be in Gaza in some form, in some fashion for some time.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: At least 120 aid trucks have entered Gaza through that Rafah Border Crossing on Sunday, we are told, by the Egyptian government. That delivery of essential supplies that so many people have gone for so long without to Gaza has been a key factor in sustaining this temporary truce between Israel and Hamas. And therefore, the exchanges of Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisoners.I want to discuss the humanitarian aspect of this with the executive director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in the United States, Mara Kronenfeld. Mara, thank you so much for being here. We've seen these truckloads of what we are told is fuel, water, food supplies going in through the Rafah Crossing into Gaza. We're told a lot of it has actually made it to north Gaza where obviously it's incredibly, desperately needed. What can you tell us about what has made it in so far?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, given that, what's the biggest challenge with getting more to the north? Is it just because it's a greater distance, or what's been the biggest obstacle so far? Is it because, I mean, it's total destruction and the roads are messed up? Or what's your sense of that?

utterances.speaker: KRONENFELD
utterances.sentences: It's safety concerns. It is -- we do know -- we have heard, at least I have heard news reports that Gazans who are coming back to their homes north of Wadi Gaza, there have been people shot at. And also I can tell you that just a couple of days ago, my dear colleague, who has been interviewed on CNN a number of times, Hani Almadhoun, his brother Majeed and Majeed's wife Safa and their four children were killed in their apartment in north Gaza.So frankly, north of Wadi Gaza is still extremely unsafe. But that said, there is no safe place in Gaza right now. And we have had 99 incidents of our own U.N. buildings being hit. Some 77 buildings have been hit, and 27 of those are direct hits, which is a clear violation of international humanitarian law.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Mara, given that, one concern had been Hamas taking this desperately needed aid for themselves, for fighters, using the fuel for their military purposes. Have you seen any evidence of that happening with this aid that's going in?

utterances.speaker: KRONENFELD
utterances.sentences: No. We don't -- UNRWA has a no-contact policy with Hamas. This aid goes directly to UNRWA, whether it's from World Food Program or from the World Health Organization, or from the Palestinian Red Crescent or elsewhere. UNRWA directly receives all of these goods and services, the vast majority of them on the other side of the Rafah Crossing. And then UNRWA trucks now that there's fuel available then takes these supplies to what are now over one million internally displaced individuals who are in UNRWA shelters.And actually 80 percent of this population of 2.2 million in Gaza, 1.7 of them, 80 percent are displaced. One million of those are in UNRWA shelters, and UNRWA provides this food and this medicine and this other support to those in these shelters.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Because they've all been forced to go to the south as a part of this war.Mara Kronenfeld, thank you for joining us with the latest update on that crucial aid in Gaza tonight.

utterances.speaker: MARQUARDT
utterances.sentences: There's a call for a hate crime investigation in Vermont after three Palestinian college students were injured in a shooting in Burlington. This is the last photo taken of the three of them before they were shot. Police say they are looking for a white male who they say opened fire without saying a word.CNN's Carlos Suarez joins us now. Carlos, what more are we learning about this?

utterances.speaker: ABED AYOUB, FAMILY ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: The suspect walked up to them and shot them. They weren't robbed. They weren't mugged. It was a targeted shooting and a targeted crime. And they were wearing the keffiyeh. They are known in the area, you know, for being Palestinian. You know, that's a very well-known symbol. It's a very well-known cloth that is very symbolic of the Palestinian cause, the Palestinian culture and history.So the fact that they were wearing this and then fell victim to a shooter leads us to believe that that played a role, their identity played a role in them being targeted. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SUAREZ
utterances.sentences: All right. So the chief of police out in Burlington said that he believes no one can really look at this incident without thinking that this was a hate-motivated crime.Alex, one final note out here. The FBI said that they are aware of this incident and that they are prepared, rather, to investigate the shooting.
